item.title: 2666, Roberto Bolano
item.description:
2666 was weird. the writing style is simple and captivating, and so much is happening (funnnily, i thought about the various sub-stories and meanderings in the mahabharata). the book about the murders of the women was a gut-punch. the book was like a rogue river, it flowed whereever it wanted, senseless and yet singular.

  1. The Part About the Critics – strange, and yet captivating. Ends senselessly.
  2. The Part About Amalfitano – didn’t understand what was going on… madness, dreams, nightmares
  3. The Part About Fate – loved this part for some reason
  4. The Part About the Crimes – hated this, but couldn’t stop reading. Gut punch after gut punch. Disgusting.
  5. The Part About Archimboldi – swirling. Felt like a fever dream, captured what an authors life may be.

item.title: The Passion According to G.H, Clarice Lispector
item.description:
• Finished reading on 26/06/2025
  • Brilliant book, 5 stars, real gut-punch
  • Disgustingly good short book
  • Disturbing, awakening
  • Themes/Thoughts:
    • Living in the moment / action orientation, rather than “hope” which is hopeless and in the future
    • The Sacred in everything, even (and especially in the profane)
    • To not construct concepts through words (like ‘beauty’, etc.)
    • To reject sensitivity and sentimentality
    • To know what you need, and to fulfill it: To strive, to live
    • To not be heroic, and to take tiny steps
    • To be inhuman, beyond human, alive
    • To be “independed”
  • Some quotes
    • “Cast of this humanization”
    • “This obsession with the future”
    • “This obsession with naming things”
    • Organizing -> leading to not experiencing
    • Material world
    • The bordom / in-between is reality
  • Key concepts
    • The limits of langauge (speaking the unknowable)
    • The collapse of identity
    • The obsession with form and destruction
    • Sacred in the profane
    • Time and being
    • Death and resurrection
    • Asking v/s Being
  • Related to
    • Neitsche, Spinoza
    • Panentheism, Buddhism
    • Confucious and Dao resolution

item.title: The Glass Bead Game
item.description:
My quick jotting down / notes… and discussions with chatgpt!

few things stood out:

  1. age of feuilleton felt very relatable to what’s happening with memes and instagram etc. right now
  2. his friends - tegularius, designori, and his influences - jacobius, music master were written well.
  3. i could see some of myself in the characters themselves: my leaving microsoft and the conversations i had then with my mentors felt parallel to the last chapter, esp. because i left at the peak; i could also relate to tegularius (overly intellectual, not in the world) and to designori (worn down by the cares of the world, stopping meditation, drinking more)… it was fascinating…

Going back to the book, The Glass Bead Game, the book seems to be written by a fairly modest biographer. Is this ironic? It makes the book harder to read than, let’s say, Siddhartha by Hermann Hesse. So clearly Hermann Hesse is a brilliant writer, but was affecting the tone of a modest biographer.

item.title: A House for Mr. Biswas
item.description: My quick jotting down… “I completed reading A House for Mr. Biswas. It was really good. I really liked how the story was just constructed really beautifully with humor, pathos, disgust, sadness. It was a great humanist novel: struggling, struggling for more, despite circumstances that hold you back, wanting more, rebelling against custom, not knowing why and yet trying to find your own path. I could imagine it made into a great movie, by someone like Satyajit Ray… overall, I loved the book.”
